faq.title: Frequently Asked Questions
faq.subtitle: Common sexual health questions and answers about this website.

q1.q: What are STIs and how are they transmitted?
q1.a: STIs (sexually transmitted infections) are infections that pass between people through sexual contact, including vaginal, anal, and oral sex. Some can also spread through skin-to-skin contact or sharing needles.

q2.q: Can I get an STI from oral sex?
q2.a: Yes. Infections like chlamydia, gonorrhea, syphilis, and HPV can be transmitted through oral sex. Using protection (e.g., condoms or dental dams) reduces risk.

q3.q: Do I need testing if I have no symptoms?
q3.a: Many STIs have no symptoms. Regular testing is recommended if you are sexually active, especially with new or multiple partners. Early detection protects you and your partners.

q4.a: Many STIs are treatable and some (like chlamydia and gonorrhea) are curable with antibiotics. Others (like HIV and herpes) can be managed with treatment to stay healthy and reduce transmission.

q5.q: How can I protect myself and my partner?
q5.a: Use condoms correctly, get tested regularly, communicate openly with partners, and avoid sex when experiencing symptoms. Vaccines (e.g., HPV, hepatitis B) also help prevent some infections.

q1.q: Is my conversation private and anonymous?
q1.a: Yes. Safhira is designed to be private and anonymous. We do not store personal chat histories.

q2.a: We base our content on guidelines from trusted health organizations and review it to ensure clarity and cultural sensitivity for Malaysians.

q3.a: No. Safhira provides educational information only and cannot replace professional medical advice, diagnosis, or treatment. Please consult a healthcare professional for concerns.

q4.a: Safhira is for anyone seeking judgment-free sexual health information, especially Malaysian teens and young adults.

list.description: Most common STI. Usually clears naturally, but high-risk types can cause cancer. Vaccine available.

list.description: Attacks immune system but highly manageable with modern treatment. People live normal lifespans.

adherence.title: Treatment Adherence

single.overview: Single‑dose treatments work best when taken exactly as prescribed at the scheduled time.
dos: Confirm timing with food/water if instructed
Set a reminder so you don’t forget
Note any side effects and how you feel
donts: Don’t split or share your dose
Don’t take extra if you vomit without clinician advice

daily.overview: Take your medicine at the same time each day. Consistency helps effectiveness and reduces missed doses.
dos: Pair doses with a daily routine (e.g., breakfast)
Use reminders and a visible pill organizer
Contact a clinician if side effects affect daily life
donts: Don’t stop early even if you feel better

multi.overview: Multi‑drug regimens may have different times/directions. Keep a simple schedule and double‑check each medicine’s instructions.
dos: List each medicine and its time
Use color labels or a weekly organizer
Ask a clinician/pharmacist if instructions conflict
donts: Don’t change dose order without guidance
Don’t mix with alcohol/OTC drugs without checking
Don’t skip monitoring or follow‑up tests

catchup.title: Missed‑Dose Catch‑up Guidance
catchup.neverDoubleDose: Never take a double dose to make up for a missed one.

single.summary: Single‑dose: Take as soon as possible unless advised otherwise.
single.details: If you missed a single‑dose treatment, take it as soon as you remember on the same day. If you vomit within a short time, contact a clinician for advice — do not re‑dose without guidance.

daily.summary: Daily course: If <12h late, take now; otherwise skip and continue.
daily.details: If you’re less than 12 hours late, take the dose now and return to your usual time. If more than 12 hours late, skip the missed dose and take the next dose at your regular time.

multi.summary: Multi‑drug: Follow drug‑specific instructions and confirm with a clinician.
multi.details: For multi‑drug regimens, follow each medicine’s catch‑up instructions. If unsure, skip the missed dose and seek clinician advice before adjusting.
